Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Sample Classification and Biomarker Discovery by Comprehensive Metabolomic Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project proposes to develop a system for automated classification of biological samples and discovery of biomarkers. The system will be designed to perform comprehensive pattern analysis of state-of-the-art biochemical separations generated by comprehensive two-dimensional chromatography (GCxGC) with high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS). The pairing of GCxGC and HRMS combines highly effective molecular separations with precise elemental analysis. A critical challenge for effective utilization of GCxGC-HRMS for biochemical sample classification and biomarker discovery is the difficulty of analyzing and interpreting the massive, complex data for metabolomic features. The quantity and complexity of the data, as well as the large dimensionality of the metabolome, and the possibility that significant chemical characteristics may be subtle and involve patterns of multiple constituents, necessitate investigation and development of new bioinformatics. The principal technical objective is an innovative framework for comprehensive feature matching and analysis across many samples. Specifically, the framework will incorporate advanced methods for multidimensional peak detection, peak pattern matching across large sample sets, data alignment, comprehensive feature matching, and multi-sample analyses (e.g., classification and biomarker discovery) with large sample sets. The anticipated result is a commercial system for automated multi-sample analysis.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be realized through improved informatics for biological classification and biomarker discovery. These tools will enable researchers to better understand biochemical processes and to discover metabolic biomarkers, which could lead to improved methods for disease diagnoses and treatments. These information technologies will foster utilization of advanced GCxGC-HRMS instrumentation, thereby contributing to the impetus for future instrument development. The informatics developed in this project also will be relevant for other classification problems involving multidimensional, multispectral data, including other applications (such as biofuels), other types of chemical analyses (such as multidimensional spectroscopy), and other fields (such as remote-sensing multispectral geospatial imagers). This project will contribute to national competitiveness in the global market for analytical technologies and will contribute to workforce development by involving students in research experiences through internships and student projects. Software developed in the project and an example dataset will be available to educational institutions to allow students to more easily explore biochemical complexity.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project investigated and developed informatics for automated classification of biological samples and discovery of biomarkers. The principle innovation of the project is the GC Image InvestigatorTM framework and supporting software tools that are capable of performing comprehensive pattern analysis of state-of-the-art biochemical separations generated by comprehensive two-dimensional gas chromatography (GCxGC) and comprehensive two-dimensional liquid chromatography (LCxLC) with high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS). While the pairing of GCxGC or LCxLC with HRMS combines highly effective molecular separations with precise elemental analysis, the effective utilization of these analytical approaches for biochemical sample classification and biomarker discovery requires effective and efficient informatics. The Investigator framework is designed for comprehensive feature generation, matching, and analysis across many samples. Specifically, the framework incorporates advanced methods for multidimensional peak detection, peak pattern matching across large sample sets, data alignment, comprehensive feature matching, and multi-sample analyses (e.g., classification and biomarker discovery) with large sample sets.

In addition, the quantity and complexity of the GCxGC and LCxLC data, as well as the large dimensionality of the metabolome and the possibility that significant chemical characteristics may be subtle and involve patterns of variations in multiple constituents, necessitate methods and tools that support rapid and effective Quality Assurance (QA), especially in commercial settings. The project developed methods and software tools for a rapid, effective QA system that provides innovative quantitative indicators of quality that can be automatically computed, interactive tools for semi-automated review, facilities for reprocessing data to improve quality, and support for multi-sample QA.

By developing and disseminating improved informatics for biological classification and biomarker discovery, the results of this project will enable applications researchers to better understand biochemical processes and to discover metabolomic biomarkers, which could lead to improved methods for disease diagnoses and treatments. These information technologies will foster utilization of advanced GCxGC-HRMS and LCxLC-HRMS instrumentation, thereby contributing to the impetus for future instrument development. The informatics developed in this project also will be relevant for other classification problems involving multidimensional, multispectral data, including other applications (such as biofuels), other types of chemical analyses (such as multidimensional spectroscopy), and other fields (such as remote-sensing multispectral geospatial imagers).

The principle innovation of the project is the GC Image InvestigatorTM framework and supporting software tools that are capable of performing comprehensive pattern analysis of state-of-the-art biochemical separations generated by comprehensive two-dimensional gas chromatography (GCxGC) and comprehensive two-dimensional liquid chromatography (LCxLC) with high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS). While the pairing of GCxGC or LCxLC with HRMS combines highly effective molecular separations with precise elemental analysis, the effective utilization of these analytical approaches for biochemical sample classification and biomarker discovery requires effective and efficient informatics. The Investigator framework is designed for comprehensive feature generation, matching, and analysis across many samples. Specifically, the framework incorporates advanced methods for multidimensional peak detection, peak pattern matching across large sample sets, data alignment, comprehensive feature matching, and multi-sample analyses (e.g., classification and biomarker discovery) with large sample sets. In addition, the quantity and complexity of the GCxGC and LCxLC data, as well as the large dimensionality of the metabolome and the possibility that significant chemical characteristics may be subtle and involve patterns of variations in multiple constituents, necessitate methods and tools that support rapid and effective Quality Assurance (QA), especially in commercial settings. The project developed methods and software tools for a rapid, effective QA system that provides innovative quantitative indicators of quality that can be automatically computed, interactive tools for semi-automated review, facilities for reprocessing data to improve quality, and support for multi-sample QA. By developing and disseminating improved informatics for biological classification and biomarker discovery, the results of this project will enable applications researchers to better understand biochemical processes and to discover metabolomic biomarkers, which could lead to improved methods for disease diagnoses and treatments. These information technologies will foster utilization of advanced GCxGC-HRMS and LCxLC-HRMS instrumentation, thereby contributing to the impetus for future instrument development. The informatics developed in this project also will be relevant for other classification problems involving multidimensional, multispectral data, including other applications (such as biofuels), other types of chemical analyses (such as multidimensional spectroscopy), and other fields (such as remote-sensing multispectral geospatial imagers).
